docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Edward Kennedy was instrumental in promoting the idea of a "war on cancer," before President Nixon made the medical challenge a public health research priority in 1971. Now nearly 40 years later, Senator Kennedy's death from brain cancer is a reminder that relatively little progress has been made in the cancer death rate in four decades, despite the many billions spent on research.

headline.main: Kennedy's War on Cancer, and Our Own

docs.abstract: What progress has been made in treatment in the last 40 years?
docs.snippet: What progress has been made in treatment in the last 40 years?

docs.lead_paragraph: BENDHEIM--Robert. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Mr. Robert Bendheim, President of the Leon Lowenstein Foundation. A thoughtful and dedicated philanthropist, Mr. Bendheim's visionary and skillful leadership of the Foundation contributed to the success of educational, scientific and social initiatives that have enriched the lives of countless individuals in this city and across the nation. At Columbia University Medical Center, Mr. Bendheim's generosity was instrumental in the formation and advancement of research and patient care programs to reduce the effects of psychiatric conditions such as depression, and numerous neurological diseases. Driven by Mr. Bendheim's compassionate concern for those in need, the Foundation established the Robert and John M. Bendheim Clinic for Movement Disorders in 2005. The facility is dedicated to improving the standard of care available to individuals affected by movement disorders such as Parkinson's disease, and has helped the women and men we serve pursue fuller and more active lives. On behalf of my colleagues, I extend my deepest sympathies and condolences to Mr. Bendheim's family and friends. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine

docs.lead_paragraph: After Amy Farber learned she had the rare and fatal disease called LAM in 2005, she became determined to increase and speed up research into her illness with the hope of finding a cure in her lifetime. Dr. Farber, now 39, was a law student with a doctorate in anthropology who was about to start a family. She quit law school and founded the LAM Treatment Alliance to raise money and connect a network of scientists around the world to research this mysterious disease, which destroys young women's lungs.
docs.abstract: Amy Farber, who was diagnosed with lymphangioleiomyomatosis in 2005 when she was 35, founded LAM Treatment Alliance to raise money and connect scientists around world who are researching rare and fatal disease; currently collaborating with Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Laboratory on LAMsight, Web site that encourages LAM patients to report on their health in order to develop databases on disease for research; critics say that there are privacy issues to consider and question validity of patient-provided data; photos (M)
